Must confess that I'm not an Apple fan either (unless used for making cider, which I used to do, but that's a whole different story), but am tempted to treat myself to an M1. But at ~£1K, I can't help wondering if a Dell XPS or something else with an i7 cpu would offer better VFM. Obviously I'd be installing Linux rather than Windows.

text: <@U02QFPDNC3W> has joined the channel

Anyone here ever been locked out of an AWS VPS instance? In my case, it's a Lightsail instance, which is basically an idiot's version of EC2. Can't login via SSH from any of my machines OR from the AWS management web page/console. Tried to reboot from AWS console but it failed. Ended up having to "stop" the instance from AWS but that also hung for a good 10+ minutes. Have been using this server for 6+ months and not had anything like it happen before.

elements.text: Anyone here ever been locked out of an AWS VPS instance? In my case, it's a Lightsail instance, which is basically an idiot's version of EC2. Can't login via SSH from any of my machines OR from the AWS management web page/console. Tried to reboot from AWS console but it failed. Ended up having to "stop" the instance from AWS but that also hung for a good 10+ minutes. Have been using this server for 6+ months and not had anything like it happen before.

text: <@U016TGY3676> few days ago my ec2 instance would only pass 1/2 status checks and i was unable to do anything with it. Probably there is some smart solution i didnt find, i ended up terminating and remaking it :smile:

text: <@U02QDLFCYHG> has joined the channel

<@U016TGY3676> I had something similar today, in my case it was because I was maxing out the cpu.  It had been fine for months, but I started running an extra flumine instance with a new strategy a couple of days ago and it couldn't cope.

My Lightsail instance was Windows (yes, yes I know! I just used that as I'm more used to Windows), but I'm going to try setting up some Unix EC2 instances instead.  As a novice Unix user has anyone got a guide on things like which flavour of Unix to use, which instance types to use (I'm thinking t3.micro), how to install Python, Git, etc, and any other tips?  I'm sure I can work it out myself, but any guidance would be appreciated.

elements.text:
I had something similar today, in my case it was because I was maxing out the cpu.  It had been fine for months, but I started running an extra flumine instance with a new strategy a couple of days ago and it couldn't cope.

My Lightsail instance was Windows (yes, yes I know! I just used that as I'm more used to Windows), but I'm going to try setting up some Unix EC2 instances instead.  As a novice Unix user has anyone got a guide on things like which flavour of Unix to use, which instance types to use (I'm thinking t3.micro), how to install Python, Git, etc, and any other tips?  I'm sure I can work it out myself, but any guidance would be appreciated.

text: Turned out that subscribing to every market on betfair uses a lot of resources. :man-facepalming: :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:

elements.text: Turned out that subscribing to every market on betfair uses a lot of resources.

text: Yeah, that would do it

elements.text: Yeah, that would do it

text: Recommend Ubuntu. Should come with Python, Git etc already installed.

elements.text: Recommend Ubuntu. Should come with Python, Git etc already installed.

text: I'd also suggest dual booting Ubuntu or Mint on one of your home machines as that will get you used to using the terminal and general layout, features, etc. Just bear in mind that a home install will have a GUI desktop, whereas a Linux server will be headless. I dual booted about 20 years ago and then found that I never booted into windows after that.

elements.text: I'd also suggest dual booting Ubuntu or Mint on one of your home machines as that will get you used to using the terminal and general layout, features, etc. Just bear in mind that a home install will have a GUI desktop, whereas a Linux server will be headless. I dual booted about 20 years ago and then found that I never booted into windows after that.

text:
Thanks, I have used Unix - we build our software at work for Windows and Unix - so I have some experience and I'm used to using the terminal, but it's not what I usually work in.

For the headless version, will it just have one terminal?  How do you get around that if you want to do more than one thing at once?

elements.text:
Thanks, I have used Unix - we build our software at work for Windows and Unix - so I have some experience and I'm used to using the terminal, but it's not what I usually work in.

For the headless version, will it just have one terminal?  How do you get around that if you want to do more than one thing at once?

text: Use tmux to run multiple terminal sessions simultaneously. <https://www.ocf.berkeley.edu/~ckuehl/tmux/>

elements.text: Use tmux to run multiple terminal sessions simultaneously.

text: Or you can just open multiple terminals on your client/local machine and SSH into the AWS instance from each.

elements.text: Or you can just open multiple terminals on your client/local machine and SSH into the AWS instance from each.

text: Perfect, thanks both

elements.text: Perfect, thanks both
